TypeSignature.Value: public sealed class InputDevice : Java.Lang.Object, Android.OS.IParcelable, IDisposable
.class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit InputDevice extends Java.Lang.Object implements class Android.OS.IParcelable, class Android.Runtime.IJavaObject, class System.IDisposable

Docs.summary: Describes the capabilities of a particular input device.

remarks.para: Describes the capabilities of a particular input device.

Each input device may support multiple classes of input. For example, a multi-function keyboard may compose the capabilities of a standard keyboard together with a track pad mouse or other pointing device.
Some input devices present multiple distinguishable sources of input. Applications can query the framework about the characteristics of each distinct source.

As a further wrinkle, different kinds of input sources uses different coordinate systems to describe motion events. Refer to the comments on the input source constants for the appropriate interpretation.

Docs.summary: The controller number for a given input device.

remarks.para: The controller number for a given input device.

Each gamepad or joystick is given a unique, positive controller number when initially configured by the system. This number may change due to events such as device disconnects / reconnects or user initiated reassignment. Any change in number will trigger an event that can be observed by registering an .
All input devices which are not gamepads or joysticks will be assigned a controller number of 0.

Docs.summary: Describe the kinds of special objects contained in this Parcelable's marshalled representation.

remarks.para: Describe the kinds of special objects contained in this Parcelable's marshalled representation.

Docs.summary: Gets the input device descriptor, which is a stable identifier for an input device.

remarks.para: Gets the input device descriptor, which is a stable identifier for an input device.

An input device descriptor uniquely identifies an input device. Its value is intended to be persistent across system restarts, and should not change even if the input device is disconnected, reconnected or reconfigured at any time.

It is possible for there to be multiple instances that have the same input device descriptor. This might happen in situations where a single human input device registers multiple instances (HID collections) that describe separate features of the device, such as a keyboard that also has a trackpad. Alternately, it may be that the input devices are simply indistinguishable, such as two keyboards made by the same manufacturer.

The input device descriptor returned by should only be used when an application needs to remember settings associated with a particular input device. For all other purposes when referring to a logical instance at runtime use the id returned by .

Docs.summary: Gets information about the range of values for a particular axis.

remarks.para: Gets information about the range of values for a particular axis. If the device supports multiple sources, the same axis may have different meanings for each source. Returns information about the first axis found for any source. To obtain information about the axis for a specific source, use .

Docs.summary: To be added.
Gets the input device id.

remarks.para: Gets the input device id.

Each input device receives a unique id when it is first configured by the system. The input device id may change when the system is restarted or if the input device is disconnected, reconnected or reconfigured at any time. If you require a stable identifier for a device that persists across boots and reconfigurations, use .

Docs.summary: Returns true if the device is a virtual input device rather than a real one, such as the virtual keyboard (see ).

remarks.para: Returns true if the device is a virtual input device rather than a real one, such as the virtual keyboard (see ).
Virtual input devices are provided to implement system-level functionality and should not be seen or configured by users.

Docs.summary: Gets the product id for the given device, if available.

remarks.para: Gets the product id for the given device, if available.
A product id uniquely identifies which product within the address space of a given vendor, identified by the device's vendor id. A value of 0 will be assigned where a product id is not available.

Docs.summary: The input source has buttons or keys.

remarks.para:
The input source has buttons or keys. Examples: , .
A should be interpreted as a button or key press.
Use to query the device's button and key mappings.

Docs.summary: The input source is a joystick.

remarks.para:
The input source is a joystick.
A should be interpreted as absolute joystick movements.
Use to query the range of positions.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype Android.Views.InputSourceType SourceClassMask = (255)

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("This constant will be removed in the future version. Use Android.Views.InputSourceType enum directly instead of this field.")

Docs.summary: A mask for input source classes.

remarks.para:
A mask for input source classes.
Each distinct input source constant has one or more input source class bits set to specify the desired interpretation for its input events.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype Android.Views.InputSourceType SourceClassNone = (0)

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("This constant will be removed in the future version. Use Android.Views.InputSourceType enum directly instead of this field.")

Docs.summary: The input source has no class.

remarks.para:
The input source has no class.
It is up to the application to determine how to handle the device based on the device type.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype Android.Views.InputSourceType SourceClassPointer = (2)

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("This constant will be removed in the future version. Use Android.Views.InputSourceType enum directly instead of this field.")

Docs.summary: The input source is a pointing device associated with a display.

remarks.para:
The input source is a pointing device associated with a display. Examples: , .
A should be interpreted as absolute coordinates in display units according to the hierarchy. Pointer down/up indicated when the finger touches the display or when the selection button is pressed/released.
Use to query the range of the pointing device. Some devices permit touches outside the display area so the effective range may be somewhat smaller or larger than the actual display size.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype Android.Views.InputSourceType SourceClassPosition = (8)

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("This constant will be removed in the future version. Use Android.Views.InputSourceType enum directly instead of this field.")

Docs.summary: The input source is an absolute positioning device not associated with a display (unlike ).

remarks.para:
The input source is an absolute positioning device not associated with a display (unlike ).
A should be interpreted as absolute coordinates in device-specific surface units.
Use to query the range of positions.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype Android.Views.InputSourceType SourceClassTrackball = (4)

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("This constant will be removed in the future version. Use Android.Views.InputSourceType enum directly instead of this field.")

Docs.summary: The input source is a trackball navigation device.

remarks.para:
The input source is a trackball navigation device. Examples: .
A should be interpreted as relative movements in device-specific units used for navigation purposes. Pointer down/up indicates when the selection button is pressed/released.
Use to query the range of motion.

remarks.para: The input source is a DPad.

remarks.para: The input source is a game pad. (It may also be a ).

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("This constant will be removed in the future version. Use Android.Views.InputSourceType enum directly instead of this field.")

Docs.summary: The input source is a device connected through HDMI-based bus.

remarks.para:
The input source is a device connected through HDMI-based bus.
The key comes in through HDMI-CEC or MHL signal line, and is treated as if it were generated by a locally connected DPAD or keyboard.

Docs.summary: The input source is a keyboard.

remarks.para:
The input source is a keyboard.
This source indicates pretty much anything that has buttons. Use to determine whether the keyboard has alphabetic keys and can be used to enter text.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype Android.Views.InputSourceType SourceMouse = (8194)

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("This constant will be removed in the future version. Use Android.Views.InputSourceType enum directly instead of this field.")

Docs.summary: The input source is a mouse pointing device.

remarks.para: The input source is a mouse pointing device. This code is also used for other mouse-like pointing devices such as trackpads and trackpoints.

Docs.summary: Gets the input sources supported by this input device as a combined bitfield.

remarks.para: Gets the input sources supported by this input device as a combined bitfield.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype Android.Views.InputSourceType SourceStylus = (16386)

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("This constant will be removed in the future version. Use Android.Views.InputSourceType enum directly instead of this field.")

Docs.summary: The input source is a stylus pointing device.

remarks.para: The input source is a stylus pointing device.

Note that this bit merely indicates that an input device is capable of obtaining input from a stylus. To determine whether a given touch event was produced by a stylus, examine the tool type returned by for each individual pointer.

A single touch event may multiple pointers with different tool types, such as an event that has one pointer with tool type and another pointer with tool type . So it is important to examine the tool type of each pointer, regardless of the source reported by .

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype Android.Views.InputSourceType SourceTouchNavigation = (2097152)

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("This constant will be removed in the future version. Use Android.Views.InputSourceType enum directly instead of this field.")

Docs.summary: The input source is a touch device whose motions should be interpreted as navigation events.

remarks.para:
The input source is a touch device whose motions should be interpreted as navigation events.
For example, an upward swipe should be as an upward focus traversal in the same manner as pressing up on a D-Pad would be. Swipes to the left, right and down should be treated in a similar manner.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype Android.Views.InputSourceType SourceTouchpad = (1048584)

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("This constant will be removed in the future version. Use Android.Views.InputSourceType enum directly instead of this field.")

Docs.summary: The input source is a touch pad or digitizer tablet that is not associated with a display (unlike ).

remarks.para: The input source is a touch pad or digitizer tablet that is not associated with a display (unlike ).

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype Android.Views.InputSourceType SourceTouchscreen = (4098)

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("This constant will be removed in the future version. Use Android.Views.InputSourceType enum directly instead of this field.")

Docs.summary: The input source is a touch screen pointing device.

remarks.para: The input source is a touch screen pointing device.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype Android.Views.InputSourceType SourceTrackball = (65540)

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("This constant will be removed in the future version. Use Android.Views.InputSourceType enum directly instead of this field.")

Docs.summary: The input source is a trackball.

remarks.para: The input source is a trackball.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype Android.Views.InputSourceType SourceUnknown = (0)

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("This constant will be removed in the future version. Use Android.Views.InputSourceType enum directly instead of this field.")

Docs.summary: The input source is unknown.

remarks.para: The input source is unknown.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance bool SupportsSource(valuetype Android.Views.InputSourceType source) cil managed

Docs.param: The input source or sources to check against. This can be a generic device type such as , a more generic device class, such as , or a combination of sources bitwise ORed together.
Docs.summary: Determines whether the input device supports the given source or sources.

remarks.para: Determines whether the input device supports the given source or sources.

Docs.summary: This API supports the Mono for Android infrastructure and is not intended to be used directly from your code.
Docs.value: A which contains the java.lang.Class JNI value corresponding to this type.

remarks.para: This property is used to control which jclass is provided to methods like .

Docs.summary: This API supports the Mono for Android infrastructure and is not intended to be used directly from your code.
Docs.value: A which provides the declaring type.

remarks.para: This property is used to control virtual vs. non virtual method dispatch against the underlying JNI object. When this property is equal to the declaring type, then virtual method invocation against the JNI object is performed; otherwise, we assume that the method was overridden by a derived type, and perform non-virtual methdo invocation.

Docs.summary: Gets the vendor id for the given device, if available.

remarks.para: Gets the vendor id for the given device, if available.
A vendor id uniquely identifies the company who manufactured the device. A value of 0 will be assigned where a vendor id is not available.

Docs.summary: Gets the vibrator service associated with the device, if there is one.

remarks.para:
Gets the vibrator service associated with the device, if there is one. Even if the device does not have a vibrator, the result is never null. Use to determine whether a vibrator is present.
Note that the vibrator associated with the device may be different from the system vibrator. To obtain an instance of the system vibrator instead, call with as argument.
